Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effect of intrauterine environment on newborn telomere length

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study telomere length in newborns and their mothers, to understand how maternal stress affects infant biology. Telomeres are structures within cells that protect and stabilize the ends of chromosomes and change in length over the life course in response to the environment. The most frequently reported interaction is telomere shortening caused by psychological and psychosocial stress. Shortened telomeres in turn have been associated with numerous diseases including diabetes, heart disease and multiple types of cancer. Some of the most exciting results to emerge recently about the intergenerational effects of maternal stress show evidence that babies exposed in utero tend to exhibit shorter telomere length (TL) at birth. This is particularly salient, as a mother's health during pregnancy has been shown to directly affect the health outcomes of her children not only at birth, but through to adulthood. As chronic stress and stress-mediated diseases are becoming increasingly prevalent in our country, the idea that trauma and stress exposure during pregnancy can create changes in a child's health outcomes, potentially through shorter telomeres at birth, has immediate public health relevance. The project will also support student training and international collaborations.

In this study the investigators will measure the TL of 100 new mothers and babies from the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), a region where war has raged for 17 years, and violence is often utilized as a systematic military tactic to intimidate the civilian population. These conditions make eastern DRC among the most stressful and traumatic environments for women to live in worldwide. By incorporating novel measures of war stress gathered via comprehensive ethnographic interviews, the hypothesis that extreme traumatic stress experienced during fetal development is associated with shortened newborn TL will be tested. Alternatively, the discovery of an association between stress and longer telomeres could suggest a pre-adaptation for life in a highly stressful environment. Finally, there is evidence that telomere attrition can be slowed by certain lifestyle changes; follow-ups will be scheduled with the children in the study to allow for TL to be measured longitudinally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, we investigated the impact of psychosocial stress on telomere length (TL) both directly and across generations. Found at the ends of chromosomes, telomeres consist of non-coding DNA repeats that function to buffer the coding portion of the genome from DNA loss. Once telomeres reach a minimal critical length, cells cease to divide. Accordingly, shorter telomeres associate with a number of age related conditions including heart disease, diabetes, and cancer. The rate of telomere shortening is also influenced by environmental factors, possibly including exposure to psychosocial stress. TL, as such, is both a plastic phenotype and novel biomarker of aging.

This project consisted of four studies. The first study was conducted as a means to both establish the relative TL assay in the Mulligan Lab, as well as address important issues of racial health inequalities experienced by African Americans. We measured TL in 157 members of the African American community in Tallahassee, FL. We then tested for associations between TL and experiences of racial discrimination. Our results indicated that not only were increased experiences of racial discrimination associated with shorter telomeres but that there also was a dose effect of four experiences of discrimination prior to a significant effect on TL being detectable. We concluded that the stress of racial discrimination may underlie the faster rate of telomere shortening seen in African Americans compared to European Americans, and may serve as a possible contributor to premature aging and racial health inequalities.

For the second study, we measured TL in 101 mother-newborn dyads from the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). The Eastern DRC has been in a state of conflict, or post conflict, since the mid 1990s and is considered to be one of the most stressful places on the planet. Here we tested if maternal experiences of war-related trauma affected TL across the maternal-fetal-placental interface. Our results indicated that while stress did not correlate with maternal or newborn TL, increased war stress associated with shorter placental telomeres. We concluded that the placenta is likely being bombarded with maternal stress hormones, such as cortisol, which may influence TL in that tissue. However, the lack of a detectable impact of war stress on newborn telomeres may reflect that many of these maternal stress hormones are inactivated before they can cross the placenta and enter the fetal blood stream.

For the third study, we measured TL in an additional 24 mother-newborn dyads from the Eastern DRC for whom we also had DNA methylation data. DNA methylation plays a role in gene expression and is the most well studied epigenetic marker. We then tested if DNA methylation patterns of eleven genes involved in telomere maintenance influenced both TL and birth weight, a trait that is reflective of newborn health. Our results indicated that while methylation of these genes did not correlate with TL, CpG sites at two genes in the placenta significantly associated with birth weight. Specifically, the genes that code for telomerase, the enzyme that rebuilds chronically short telomeres (TERT), and an important telomerase inhibitor (POT1). Telomerase activity in the placenta previously correlated with adverse birth outcomes related to low birth weight, including intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia. We concluded that DNA methylation of genes associated with telomerase in the placenta could be intermediating the effect of telomerase activity on birth weight. 

The fourth study is ongoing. We are currently measuring TL from follow up samples collected from the Congolese newborns. We hope that this project will allow for the better characterization of how TL changes during the first few years of life.

For this project, we generated novel TL data from Congolese and African American samples. We demonstrated the value of using culturally relevant measures of stress in studies of telomere diversity and highlighted the importance of utilizing a multidisciplinary approach to study human health. All TL data will be freely accessible on the Institutional Repository at the University of Florida (http://ufdc.ufl.edu/l/ufir) upon publication of our results.
